direction.raw_text: as hard as you can. We watch our hand gripping hers, and as we hold on, the sights and sounds around us grow more clear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's over, and I've got you, and you're safe. You're safe now. You got that? Don't let go. Don't let me go. But our eyes unlock from Sharon's and DRIFT TO a patch of night sky. Her voice fades awawy. Our POV begins TO LIFT, MOVING TOWARD that sky, as the blue-black night begins to turn white. We GO INTO that white light and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That car is older than they are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chevy Impala.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what I said. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Needs a servicing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't we all. Robby nearly spits his coffee, laughing at what Sharon has said and trying not to choke. Sharon smiles, shaking her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get it together, officer. As Robby smiles, Sharon looks ahead at the young couple who each have an arm around the other. She is stroking his neck. He is making gentle circles in her hair. Sharon watches this, and for a moment her eyes reveal a depth that may be loneliness, but she quickly pushes her thoughts away and hits the HORN, startling Robby and startling the people ahead who now disengage and drive on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus, Pogo! Almost spilled my coffee again! You didn't like his hair, or what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love Elvis hair. They were going two damn miles an hour. But Robby's eyes have caught something on the monitor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's roll to this -- fight in progress. As Robby secures that coffee cup, Sharon hits the SIREN and speeds around the car in front of them. EXT. CITY STREET - DAY At the same time, a few blocks away, an OLD, FRAIL MAN is carrying two plastic grocery bags that are too heavy for him. Walking behind this man is a younger man named CATCH LAMBERT, an attractive man with some scarring on his face. His eyes, deep down, are haunted by something, but there is energy in his step. He is dressed in a relaxed and stylish manner, not expensive. He begins to pick up his pace to catch up to the old man. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: People glance at Catch, nad he glances back in an open and unflinching way, ready for anything, a smile, a nod, or -- because these are some of L.A.'s mean streets -- a threatening or taunting look. These he also meets openly, without a trace of fear. The man has been through some kind of fire, and it has left him different from us. Outside the usual boundaries. Catch walks beside the Old Man, glancing at him. Finally, the man glances back, wondering and suspicious, but Catch has a slight, disarming smile, open and honest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Y'know... since we're both walking the same way, I could take one of those bags for you. That way, I do some upper body work while I'm walking along. Helps my back. What d'you say? The Old Man trudges on, proud and suspicious, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right now your mind's making pictures of me robbing your groceires, but, y'know, nine times out of ten, people do the right thing. The Old Man glances at him, still not convinced, but he soon has to stop and rest. Catch stops, too. The old man looks at him, a bit embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the dog food that makes it so heavy. Catch nods, puts out his hand. The Old Man hesitates, then decides and lifts a bag, and Catch takes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess it's worth it... for a good dog. Catch isn't kidding. He has that honesty. The Old Man nods and starts trudging again. As they walk on together, Catch reaches for that second bag. The man relents and lets him take it. They continue on, Catch carrying the bags and every now and then lifting them a bit for his upper body work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. VIDEO GAME ROOM - DAY This is the call Sharon and Robby have sped to. It is a chaotic scene of cops breaking up a fight between eight boys, 16-20. A big KID, 18 or so, is being pulled off another by Sharon and Robby. The Kid is wild and resisting and Sharon shows her toughness and professionalism and some anger, too, as she slams him into a fence -- and Robby holds him while she cuffs the young man -- who is very mouthy, playing to his friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at this bitch.    Whoo!   Benny, look at this! Sharon and Robby are both very good at their jobs, taking this Kid to their car while other cops contain the rest. A crowd watches -- mostly teens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Sharon) You come in with me.    Hey, bitch. Some of his bystanders friends howl at that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're going to arrest me, you come into the back seat with me. Come on! He resists a bit, but they're getting him into the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on.   We'll have a good time. INT. POLICE CAR - DAY (FEW MINUTES LATER) Sharon's on the radio to dispatch as Robby drives and the Kid keeps mouthing off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to radio) Three Adam Five -- show us 1019 to the jail with one male prisoner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take off your uniform. Take off my handcuffs, bitch, and come back here. I want one touch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give it a rest! Sharon is stone-faced through this. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you're going to put me away, you gotta give me one sweet touch. INT. JAIL BOOKING AREA - DAY As Robby and Sharon bring their suspect to the booking counter, each holding one of his cuffed arms. The Kid is looking at Sharon's hand on his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That ain't the touch.   That ain't the touch I want. They get him to the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As I remove your cuffs, I want you to put your hands here. Spread your legs. More. As they remove the cuffs, the Kid makes a sudden move toward Sharon, reaching between her legs -- but she was not only ready for this, but hoping for it -- and the stoniness of her face cracks into fierce anger as she moves quickly and grabs the Kid by the hair, bringing his face into her upraised knee. He cries out and goes down on his knees, hurting and bleeding. The jailer rushes over to help, but Robby grabs the Kid's wrists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's it.   Back off, John, we got it. Robby glances at Sharon -- a dark glance. EXT. POLICE JAIL PARKING LOT - DAY (LATER) as Robby and Sharon walk to their car. They are interrupted by one of their lieutenants, SANDERMAN, walking their way and stopping to stare at Sharon. She meets his look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You trying to be a bad-ass, Pogue? She is straightforward, not rebellious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just dealt with the situation. The prisoner... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you don't see a pattern here? (pause) I want you to keep yourself way inside the line instead of walking on it. All right? Are you taking notes? He walks away, and Sharon and Robby walk on to their car -- she is dark; he is glancing at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You broke his nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grabbed me.     End of story.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you were waiting for him. You were hoping. You were making long-range plans for his ass while he was mouthing off in the car -- and you're supposed to be above that shit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you think I crossed the line, put it in the report.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pogo, stop the shit. What is it? You pissed off at me, too? They enter the car, Sharon behind the wheel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not you, Rob. You're a rare unthreatened male cop with a good marriage, and you like to eat where I eat -- so everything's code four. She STARTS the CAR and starts to back out, and he reaches over and turns OFF the IGNITION. She stares hotly at him -- but then, slowly, she softens, takes a deep breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come over    for dinner tonight. I'll call    Charlene. She'd like to see you.     It's been awhile. We'll talk about    it. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: She STARTS the CAR again, more calm, starts to drive out of the lot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks. But  she'll invite friends, try and fix me up. She's always trying to fix me up so she doesn't have to worry about you and me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She doesn't worry about that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all worry about that. They both smile wryly, driving on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't need to fix me, Robby, or fix me up. I don't want some guy to heart and soul me and then walk away 'cause he can't stand the cop thing -- or worse: he wants cop stories every night 'cause it turns him on, and he has no idea who I am inside my head. Anyway, I'm busy tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Got some action, huh?    Well, that's promising.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.   Hot and heavy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: In the glow of a street lamp, Catch sees a bright-colored object in the gutter. He picks it up out of the gurgling rain water. It is a small toy, a discarded superhero. He puts it in his pocket, walks on. Now the car, the prowling, MUSIC-BLASTING, BASS- THUNDERING CAR turns a corner and begins rollling along slowly -- beside Catch. He glances over, walking on. There are four tough-looking MEN in the car, looking for trouble. The MUSIC is DEAFENING. Catch glances again, walks on. Their eyes follow him like gun barrels. He stops and walks out on the street, moving toward the car, shouting over the music.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey! You want to turn that volume down? What's your point? The men, incredulous, stop the car and snap OFF the MUSIC in order to make sure they're hearing right. They stare death at Catch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did you say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the point of blasting your music through the whole zip code? Don't you realize there are kids trying to sleep in these apartments -- old people, sick people? They can hardly believe this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You better watch your mouth, asshole. Catch meets the man's look with his own unflinching, haunted eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?   What're you gonna do?   Kill me? Catch's look is not a macho challenge. It's something else -- beyond that, a man somehow without limits. One of the riders in the backseat taps the Driver's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Guy's nuts.   Let's go. The Driver, never breaking his death stare, snaps on the DEAFENING MUSIC and then slowly rolls on, still glaring at Catch. Catch stands in the rain, watching them go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. CATCH'S APARTMENT CORRIDOR - SAME NIGHT Catch is arriving home, soaking wet. He lives in a slightly-seedy three-story. As he walks down the corridor toward his apaprtment, he passes a neighbor's door and notices a set of keys dangling from the lock. He pauses -- and then knocks softly on the door. Someone looks through the peephole and then opens the door -- a young single mother, friendly but with a little caution, too. She recognizes Catch. Behind her is a little boy, (five). The woman's name is CANDACE. Her son is TOMMY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi.   Your keys are in the... He gestures, and she sees the keys and retrieves them, more friendly now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, thank you. Thanks a lot. God. I was trying to carry Tommy and all these bags. He was so tired. Of course, as soon as I put him down he had all this energy... While she is talking, Catch is staring deeply at the boy, who is shy. Catch almost speaks to the boy, wants to, goes halfway to a smile -- but the sight of the kid stirs that layer of darkness in Catch. He nods a good-bye to the mother and is about to go. She thinks about this, as he is turning, and pushes through her remaining caution to say...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Y'know, we were just baking nectarine bars because the peaches weren't ripe. Ever had a nectarine bar? He smiles and seems to want to stay, but he is already retreating. His contact goes only so far -- and no further.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry.   Gotta be going. And with one more glance at the boy, he walks to his apartment, unlocks it and steps in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. CATCH'S APARTMENT - NIGHT He walks into a bare living room -- no chairs, tables, lamps, nothing on the walls. He walks into a spotless, never-used kitchen and flips on the light, opens a drawer. In the drawer is a collection of kids' toys, some found, some purchased, mostly plastic figures. The action of opening the door has started some battery-operated animals moving around in there. Now from his pocket he takes the plastic superhero he just found and drops it in and closes the drawer. He walks back into the living room. He sits on the floor, leans back against the wall, his clothes still soaked from the rain. He stares at his thoughts, looking a bit numb -- and lost. EXT./INT. DRY CLEANERS SHOP - DAY Sharon is just leaving with a clean uniform on a hanger in a plastic bag. It's a neighborhood place where alterations are done. As she is leaving, an older woman is just entering. This is MRS. VANDER, beaming at Sharon, a real talker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sherry!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Mrs. Vander. You're looking good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, you just wait. I splurged. She is pulling a new blue dress out of a shopping bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's for the church and the party. It's just a little too long.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looks great.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Y'know, I cried over the invitation -- just imagine me in church. (laughs) It'll be so good to spend time with you. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: Sharon forces a smile -- but is mystified. Mrs. Vander is walking to the counter and pausing to say...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know Dan and I   renewed our vows last year. I    bet that's where your mom got   the idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their vows?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your mom and dad -- the ceremony... Mrs. Vander realizes what's going on and stammers on, sympathetic and embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, well... y'know, I just got that invitation a few... just now, so I'm sure you'll...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yeah. We've had... there's been some problems with the mail in our building, so... I'll probably get it today. They're both covering like mad, both realizing Sharon's been left out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, I guess I'll see you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, honey.     I'll see you there. Sharon leaves -- Mrs. Vander staring after her, feeling bad. As Sharon walks away, we see her forced smile die, replaced by an old pain and darkness. EXT. RESIDENTIAL STREET - DAY Robby and Sharon's unit pulls up at a house remodel with a sign marked "POGUE CONSTRUCTION." Sharon exits the car and walks onto the site, moves toward a man who is both carpenter and supervisor on the job. This is her brother, LARRY POGUE, 29. They are not comfortable with each other -- an old wound. He gives her a wary nod. She's trying a little harder, being a bit more friendly. We can sense the strain. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't see his truck, so...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's not here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How you doing? She touches his shoulder as she says this, a friendly gesture, a reaching out. He doesn't respond, only shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kathy and the boy? Bet he's big now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Growin' fast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is he looking more like you now -- or did he get lucky? She has broken through a bit and they both smile a brief, wry smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's got Kathy's looks and brains and my strong back. You should feel his grip. (pause) You just passing by? She looks about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Place is coming along nice. The octagon window. Dad's signature. But Larry's look stays on her, wondering what's on her mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, Larry, I shouldn't have to hear it from Mrs. Vander -- about what's happening. He turns back to his work now as they speak, uncomfortable. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's happening?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you really weren't going to tell me? Nobody was going to tell me? Mom and Dad renewing their vows, the church, the party. Mrs. Vander is all excited. She bought a new dress. It's blue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're workin' on Dad. We think you should be there. We told him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom told him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We mentioned it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's holding out, hah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want to come?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's my family. Jesus, Lar. It's over ten years, and he won't let go of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You two were always head to head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For good reason. Remember?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's just leave it. She stares, then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're still scared of him. Pissed, he throws his hammer down on the plywood, turns to her. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think it's a good idea you coming around here in uniform. People see it, they think we're in trouble here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice seeing you, too. She walks away.     He frowns, picks up his hammer, goes back to work. ON STREET As Sharon walks towards the car, she sees a van approaching and she holds up a hand to Robby and calls out...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two more minutes. And she walks toward the oncoming van, which is parking now. EXT. VAN - DAY The van is driven by KATHY, Sharon's brother's wife. Beside her in a car seat is LARRY, JR., four years old. Sharon comes to the rolled down window on the driver's side. She has a warm smile for Kathy and the child. Kathy smiles, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi! Look -- it's your Auntie Sharon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Champ, my God, look how big. She has a special affection for the boy -- who is subdued, but he smiles a small one for his aunt. She takes one of his hands and they shake in mock formality.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ow! You hurt my hand with that grip. Whew. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: She shakes her fingers, and he smiles a bit more. Sharon reaches in and rubs his head in a mock knuckling move. He laughs. She smooths his hair, affectionately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're bringing Larry his lunch. Hey, it's good to see you. It's been awhile. What? Sharon is staring at Kathy's badly bruised ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I went boom into a low shelf
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT. LOS ANGELES CITYSCAPE - DAY We PICK OUT a police car from the traffic and FOLLOW. The beat being patrolled is a mixed neighborhood with some very rough edges. INT. POLICE CAR - DAY Officer Sharon Pogue is driving the car. It is two years since we saw her at the accident site. Her partner, ROBBY LEWIS, sips coffee and keeps one eye on the CAD monitor which lists all area police calls. She slows behind a car that is crawling along, an old 60s car, driven by a young man and woman who sit very close on the bench seat. The car's ENGINE is MISSING and smoking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. SHARON'S APARTMENT - NIGHT She is on the floor using an exercise rig, sliding into crunches, pushing herself, sweating, alone. We BEGIN DRIFTING TO the rain-spattered window as night sounds filter in, HORNS, SOMEONE SHOUTING, a CAR MOVING BY with THUNDEROUS BASS MUSIC that pulses the very air and RATTLES the LOOSE GLASS of her window. EXT. NEIGHBORHOOD STREETS - NIGHT Catch Lambert is walking the wet streets, head down in the rain. Far away we hear that car with a BASS-BLASTING RADIO. (CONTINUED)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: chasing after him of course. (nodding to the child) How're you doing? Sharon pulls her eyes off the bruise to meet Kathy's look -- and connect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm semi-okay. I heard about the... ceremony and the party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. I hope you'll be there. (pause) Really. Sharon smiles a bit, appreciating the support.       She pats Kathy's arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take it easy.    You too, Champ. The boy offers his little hand to shake again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, no. You're not breaking my fingers again. They smile and drive on and Sharon walks toward her car and Robby. EXT. CITY PARK - DAY (NEXT DAY) We WATCH moms and kids and a basketball game in the park and PICK UP Catch walking by. Two pre-teens are playing bounce and catch with a rubber ball against a (tennis practice) wall, and one of them misses, and Catch makes a lunge and snags the ball. Instead of throwing it to one of the boys, he fires it at the wall. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: One of the boys catches it, bounces it off the wall toward Catch. Catch grabs it, and now he's part of this rapid-fire game -- and he's athletic and funny, too, playing hard and mugging and making them smile until... a POLICE CAR comes ROARING down the boulevard, slowing a bit to CHIRP its SIREN a few times -- clearing traffic. Catch glances up and sees... CATCH'S POV Sharon is in the car beside Robby. ON CATCH Stunned by the sight of her -- and he doesn't know why. He can't move, can't breathe, eyes fixed on her. The POLICE CAR pulls around a truck and ROARS on -- and that's when he is struck by a memory, a little like lightning. It comes as a quick -- FLASHBACK - EXT. FREEWAY - ACCIDENT SITE    - CATCH'S POV -- The man near death. Sharon is bending close to him, this all just a sliver of an image, and it jolts him. BACK TO SCENE (PRESENT) The police car is now converging with other squads just half a block away. Catch throws the ball back to the boys and runs toward the police incident. The boys watch him go, wondering. EXT. CLOSED STORE - DAY A police   car is parked askew near this closed store -- as now Robby   and Sharon's UNIT ROARS to a STOP beside it. Two cops   are calling and motioning to them, one holds a shotgun.    This is RAY JULIETTE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Break-in alarm. One suspect in -- nobody out. Take the back. And they are moving. EXT. BACK OF CLOSED STORE - DAY Robby and Sharon are hurrying around to the back as we hear more POLICE UNITS CONVERGING in front.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ANGLE - STREET As Catch arrives on the scene and sees Sharon and Robby moving around the building to the back. He is still amazed at the sight of her. He decides to follow her, keeping her in sight, driven. ON SHARON, ROBBY They are scouting through crates and weeds as a young man is flushed from cover at the back of the store and runs from them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Freeze! The man runs on, and Sharon chases with Robby close behind her. Sharon speaks to her shoulder radio mike as she runs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to radio) Three-A-5, foot pursuit. Suspect fleeing south on Pico Place, young man, green jacket. No visible weapon... (to Robby) Robby!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right behind you! (to man) Stop and lie down with your arms... shit. The man has jumped a fence.   Sharon follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Careful!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see him! She goes over the fence, then Robby. EXT. PARKING LOT - DAY The man runs and Sharon chases. Robby, not far behind glances off to the side, seeing Catch, still following.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Citizen on your right!   Hey! (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: But Sharon is now closing on the fleeing man who turns suddenly, pointing a handgun!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gun! And Sharon, wide-eyed, is already pulling her weapon, but not in time. The man is aiming at her and about to fire when he is tackled by Catch. Catch and the man go sprawling, and the gun flies out of the man's hand, and Sharon is on him in an instant, pointing her gun at him...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Freeze!    Right there! Catch scrambles to his feet. Robby joins Sharon and puts his knee in the man's back and cuffs him, then glances at Catch. So does Sharon. But Catch starts to hurry off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey!     Wait! Two other cops (Ray Juliette and SANCHEZ) rush toward the suspect on the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was armed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Citizen took him down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No shit!? Sharon stares across the lot to where Catch has halted. More cops are converging. Ray Juliette and Sanchez move toward Catch, while a sergeant and others surround Sharon and the suspect. In between the crowd of cops, Catch and Sharon glance at each other, during... ON CATCH as the cops reach him. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... just saw it and... I saw the gun, so... ON SHARON ROBBY You all right, Pogo? She is shaken, speaks softly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was dead.   Y'know. She glances toward Catch. (She doesn't recognize him from the accident.) Their eyes meet briefly, but then their attention is pulled to the others. Sharon speaks to her sergeant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He had me.    I was dead. ON CATCH He is shaken, too.    Sanchez is taking notes as Ray checks his I.D.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was just walking by.      I live near here. Ray nods, handing the I.D. to Sanchez.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sergeant's going to want to talk to you, Mr. Lambert. We'll need a statement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry about it. That's just procedure. Look -- we appreciate what you did. No bullshit. Let us buy you a drink tonight, all right? You know where the Rib House is? Catch glances at Sharon again, and he nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. UPSCALE RESIDENTIAL NEIGHBORHOOD - DAY (SAME DAY) Catch, a bit bruised and dirty from his tackle, is carrying groceries up the walkway steps to a small, well- kept home. He is taking out a key as he walks to the covered portico. INT. MRS. CHU'S HOME - DAY ELANORA CHU, 60, is an attractive woman with warmth and intelligence in her eyes. She is in a wheelchair, at a writing table where she carefully translates an English text into Chinese characters. She glances up as Catch opens the front door and heads for the kitchen, speaking as he goes, not looking at her or into the living room at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got you nectarines because the peaches are hard as rocks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your jacket's all dirty. She rolls away from the table in her motorized chair -- and as they speak across the house, she performs a ritual...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I tackled a guy. Elanora is moving about the living room, picking up framed photographs and turning them face down. We don't see what -- or who -- is in these photos. She is turning them all in a routine way, used to this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why would you 'tackle' a guy?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do you think? INT. KITCHEN - DAY Catch is at the cupboards, putting away groceries as Elanora rolls into the kitchen, her CHAIR HUMMING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He had the ball. He was going for a touchdown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you be serious? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What day is today?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wednesday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. They are not smiling at their little jokes, but they have an ease with each other and the deep love of dear friends. He doesn't pause in his work, but we can see some nervousness in him as he says...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Met somebody today. Mrs. Chu is now taking some of the groceries out of the bags to help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh? That's good. Ahh -- they had the broccolini today. Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A woman. Elanora is more interested and curious now, still helping with the groceries and being casual.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't tackle her, too, did you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good, Catch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's a police officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you in trouble? Catch goes on working, a depth in his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.   No trouble. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: Elanora watches him work and gladdens slightly.     We see her own depth of feeling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... that's a good thing. He is still working, but his eyes are on his thoughts, his struggle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I saw her once a long time ago. Elanora stares a moment.      This has meaning for her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where? He doesn't answer.      He's nervous about this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks the same. Now she watches him as he moves to the refrigerator and continues his work in silence. INT. RIB HOUSE - THAT NIGHT It's a noisy restaurant with a large bar area. We PAN TO a booth of off-duty cops, out of uniform now, including Ray, Sanchez, Sharon and a few more male officers. They're all a bit high. Sharon shows the signs, too. They are passing around a photo now as one COP looks at it and says...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beautiful. ... And Sanchez says proudly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. My wife's got him in agility class.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No shit. Ray is handed the photo, and we see that they're talking about Sanchez's dog, the name "REX" printed on the photo. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Rex.' Rex is good. I wonder who the first person was to name a dog 'Fido,' and what the hell does it mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like how you're always asking the big questions, Ray. There is some laughter.     Ray is a smart-ass and a flirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got a big question for you, Pogo
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: but I can only ask it when we're alone. She moves some of the change on the table, sliding it toward Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here -- use this -- call your wife and ask her instead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I happen to know Ray's wife is busy tonight. They laugh and drink and Ray asks her...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why doesn't your partner ever come out with us?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Robby's a family man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a family man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, but his family actually likes him. More laughter. Sharon's eyes do a quick roam of the bar. Ray catches this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That Lambert -- I guess he's not showing either. She shrugs this off like it's not important and starts to slide out of the booth. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The head.   Do you mind?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's just gonna freshen up her makeup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're wearing makeup? She leaves the booth with a wry frown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That reminds me, Ray. You still have that eye-liner you borrowed from me? She grins, leaving the laughter behind her. ANGLE - DOOR Catch has entered the bar. He is watching Sharon leave the booth and walk to the rest rooms. He looks back at the raucous booth and hesitates. He sits at a small table near the door. INT. BATHROOM - NIGHT Sharon is drying her hands in the bar's bathroom, staring into the mirror. No smile now. We see into her mind for a second. FLASHBACK - MAN Pointing the gun at her face today. BACK TO SHARON (PRESENT) in the mirror and see how shaken she still is. ON CATCH A waitress is leaving his table, and he looks back at Sharon's booth and sees that she still isn't there. He starts to turn, and then freezes as he hears... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There you are. She has stepped out of the bathroom and spotted him.      He is surprised, face to face now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We thought you wouldn't show.    Why you sitting here? He shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't talk to a lot of people. Would you...? He half rises and gestures to the other chair. She glances back at her booth, then sits. She's nervous, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't have a chance to thank you. I'm Sharon Pogue. She puts out her hand. He stares at that hand for just half a beat before taking it. They shake. The feel of her hand holding his evokes the memory of the accident, but he covers this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look familiar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess I live on the beat you patrol. Her way to cover nervousness is to be blunt, even tough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why would you do that -- jump a man with a gun?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was going to shoot you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He could've shot you. You have a death wish? You a bungee jumper?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I didn't have time to think about it. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What d'you think about it now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I figure... it was worth the risk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For someone you don't even know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah -- and for what you do. I think cops are great. Out there, trying to keep it safe. You know? Tough job. Firemen are everybody's heroes. Kids wave at firemen. People should wave at cops. Did you ever think about how many people are walking around this town because you saved them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never thought about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... because you helped them or because you arrested somebody who would've hurt them or because you just... did your job?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now I'm walking around this town because of you. Ever think about that? Maybe you should be a cop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know... I look pretty dumb in a hat... He has made her smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... and I don't drive and, like I said, I don't talk to many people. Am I talking too much? I am. You go ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. What d'you do? You employed around here? Oh, God. Sorry. Every time I try to talk to somebody, it comes out like an interrogation. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where do you want to be ten years from now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Somebody taught that to me. Kind of a shortcut. You ask somebody, what are your plans for tomorrow -- what're your dreams for ten years from now. It's supposed to get things started.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does it work?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never tried it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bullshit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Really. I just remembered it
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God is my witness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not in here.    It's mostly cops. Now she has made him smile, the first real smile we've seen from Catch. It's open and real and she is charmed by it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have a nice smile. She's a bit self-conscious, saying that, and just as she says it, the waitress arrives with shots and beers for both of them. Sharon looks up, questioning, and the waitress nods toward the booth. Catch and Sharon see the cops, staring, smiling, raising their glasses. There is a hint of teasing in their grins. And now Sharon is more self-conscious, and a bit tough again, taking her drink and turning back to Catch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So... what were we talking about? Oh, yeah, you were giving me some line about starting a conversation. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The shortcut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.    I'll play. They clink glasses and drink.         Then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tomorrow I've got a night watch shift. If the weather clears, in the morning I'll go hiking. If it rains, I'll go to the gym -- and the laundromat. Ten years from now... I want to be living in some mountainous place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tibet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could be Tibet. Could be Colorado. Your turn. But now Ray Juliette is approaching the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Pogo -- don't keep him all to yourself. Come on over, Lambert, join the group. We'll buy you dinner, give you a medal for saving Pogo's ass. Sharon drains her shot and stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Actually, I'm kind of tired, Ray. I'm taking off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh.     I'll... walk you to your car. Catch stands and turns to Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks for the drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Least we could do. We don't like her very much -- but we don't want to lose her. Sharon frowns and waves to the booth of cops.        Ray smiles and shakes hands with Catch as a good-bye. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take care. And Catch and Sharon leave. EXT. BAR - NIGHT As Catch and Sharon exit the building, walk toward her car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not a great neighborhood. Maybe I should walk you to your car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't have a car. They walk on, silent a moment.      This doesn't come easy for her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Want a ride home?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, thanks, but... I like to walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's starting to rain.   Don't be a hero. He hesitates, nervous about it, but then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. If it's no trouble. Thanks. They walk to her car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay... ten years from now, what d'you want to be doing? They walk side by side a moment.      He shrugs.   Then -- in his open way...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.    This is pretty good. She glances at him, taking this in, then fumbles a bit with her car keys, and he asks -- nervously again... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you drive okay? She gets a little defensive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not drunk. You think I'm drunk? I'm not. You'll know I'm drunk when I'm throwing up, and I never throw up, so don't worry about it. He nods, looks at her dead-on a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The only time I worry is when people tell me not to worry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get in the car, will you? INT. CAR - NIGHT As they get in and she STARTS the ENGINE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm on Lundy Street, just off Pico. They drive a while. She notices his anxiety.     He grips the armrest when she speeds up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm good at this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Streets are wet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you one of those people who drive ten miles an hour in the rain? I hate that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never drive. She glances at him, and he notices her glance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be alright. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: He's forcing himself to relax. He takes a deep breath, sitting back in his seat. He watches her as she drives. After a moment...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Y'know, I can picture you in Colorado.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yeah?   What am I doing there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Driving around... pissed off. She smiles in spite of herself, slows down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not pissed off at you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me some time. Now she laughs. She drives, not to his building, but to her own street. She parks, takes a deep breath. This sounds a bit hard-bitten because she's using her toughness to cover.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Those guys  in the bar are my friends --  sort of. We work together,  we tell jokes and we bullshit,  but I can't say to them... She halts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? She says this clipped and fast and even tougher:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Every time I close my eyes, I see that goddamn gun pointing at me and I don't know why I'm telling you unless it's because you were there and because I had three drinks, but I'm not ready to go inside and close my eyes and I don't want to go to your place and I don't want to keep driving around, so what the hell do we do? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whew. I feel like we're boxing, and you've got me on the ropes. (pause) We'll do whatever you want.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What I want  is to know how you happened to  be walking by that parking lot  at that minute. What if you hadn' t been there? For a moment, she shows her fear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess we were supposed to meet. They stare a while, then she opens her door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you want -- you can come in for a minute. INT. SHARON'S APARTMENT - NIGHT As they walk in, she moves into the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Want a drink?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No thanks. She pours one for herself while he looks about. It's a stiff drink. Now that he's here, her I-don't-want-to- make-a-fool-of-myself alarm is on. She flops on the sofa, watches him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit down or something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm circling awhile. He's looking around at the clutter of her life -- the intimate details.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not supposed to look around. I didn't have time to straighten up. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So... it's more real this way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's rude. He turns to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now that I'm in here, you seem mad about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not mad. You'll know when I'm mad. I don't usually let somebody in here, but here you are. That's all. Let's talk about something stupid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You first. She smiles in spite of herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay -- one thing I don't believe is that 'supposed to' business. We were 'supposed to' meet. That sounds a little fringy to me, like something you might hear on public access TV. You believe that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some people say we each give off a particular odor -- that can only be detected by one other person's brain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, we... smell each other?   Who says that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have no idea. (as they smile) I'm more in the destiny school, we-met-in-another-life school. Do you believe that? Do you think when we die -- we come back in another form? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean like   a duck? No. I think dead is   dead. I've been thinking about   it all day -- and I don't want to   think about it anymore. He looks at her, steps close to her, takes the drink out of her hand, puts it to his lips and drinks it all down. He puts the glass on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why'd you do that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See?   Now you're thinking about me. She gets a half smile, assessing him. Her look is direct, and the attraction is there. He feels it, too, and he deflects it, nodding toward a large photomural of snowcapped mountains.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me guess.       Colorado.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Austria, but I can't picture myself in Austria. I'm not good with languages, so I couldn't qualify for the departments over there. She rises and goes to a desk and takes the holstered gun off her ankle. She takes the cuffs off her belt, the mace from her jacket, the shield from her shirt pocket, puts them all in a desk drawer. She takes off her jacket and throws it over a chair. Disarmed, she turns to him. Her look is all wanting and pushing away, almost fierce in her struggle. He sees this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks for... coming up here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does that mean I'm going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.    You don't have to.    I...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You okay now? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: Her eyes grow a bit hard, defensive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh.    You're here as a medic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this the mad part? She smiles in spite of herself -- again. He has gotten to her. She wants to fall into this guy, but she's pumping those brakes. They are standing close together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe going is a good idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I come back some time?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Must be the smell. That makes her laugh, and her resistance falls away with her surprised laughter, and she puts her hands around the back of his neck. Her touch is electric to him. She is going in for a kiss, and he is retreating. They stare a moment -- and then he suddenly takes her shoulders and lets loose his own longing. It is a hungry and passionate kiss, and in the very midst of it, he breaks off and pulls back, his darkness rushing at him. She is staring, surprised, and he is looking a bit shaken, getting the words out just above a whisper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I better go. She doesn't know what to say. The moment hangs. He leaves. Once he closes the door, the breath escapes her, and she shakes her head -- feeling like an idiot. She lost control. With a stranger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, God. EXT. STREET - NIGHT Catch leaving Sharon's building in a turmoil of emotions, staring hard at his thoughts -- and he steps into the path of a car. The CAR SCREECHES to a stop, and the scream of those brakes and white light of the head lamps paralyze Catch, and he sees -- 37. FLASHBACK - SLIVER OF IMAGE Headlights suddenly washing into a vehicle he is driving. BACK TO SCENE    (PRESENT) This sliver of memory jolts HIM -- and then another one comes. FLASHBACK - HEADLIGHTS coming closer and the scream of brakes from his memory, and all of this is exploded -- BACK TO SCENE    (PRESENT) by the angry DRIVER shouting at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell do you think you're doing?! Catch is numb -- completely shut down there in the middle of the street. The Driver exits his car and comes toward him, raging.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you crazy?! Catch isn't even aware of him. The man gawks at this -- and now Catch walks off. It is raining. The streets are wet. ANGLE - RESIDENTIAL STREET - NIGHT As Catch continues his walk, he is still a bit shaken -- but when he passes a parked car with the window half open, rain getting in, he hesitates. He can't just walk on. He looks about. He tests the lock. He opens the door, rolls up the window, closes the door, walks on. But a MAN is just exiting a doorway to the street -- and calls out...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey!    Hey!   What did you do? Catch stops and turns in the rain.     The Man hurries toward him, upset, angry. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's my car!     What the hell were you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing.    I just... The Man shoves him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I saw you!    What did you take out of there?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I rolled up the window.       It's rain... The Man gets in his face, shaky...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You take my phone?!       Hah?! He shoves Catch again, and Catch's desperate confusion explodes in a surprising reaction, grabbing the Man's jacket front in one hand and not punching him but quickly slap, slap, slapping him, saying...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey!   Hey!    Wake up!    Wake up! The Man is now speechless, frozen, terrified, as Catch's eyes hold him with a fierceness -- and a sadness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I helped you. (pause) I helped you. Catch lets him go, and immediately begins walking away, hunching into the rain, his expression dark and troubled. He gets five steps away and turns. The Man steps back -- but Catch only says...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. And he walks on.        The Man watches him go. INT. CATCH'S APARTMENT BUILDING CORRIDOR - NEXT DAY Candace, Catch's neighbor, is waiting for the slow, RATTLING ELEVATOR with her son. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: The elevator door opens -- and there is Catch, seated on a newly-bought wicker chair in the elevator with a small table across his lap, other boxes nearby and a long-stemmed rose in his hand, wrapped for giving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh.   Sorry. He rises and hurriedly gets his purchases off the elevator so the woman and little boy can enter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shopping day? He smiles at her, a bit less subdued than before as he gets his things into the hall -- and he manages a special look for Tommy, a wink. He frees the elevator; they step inside. As the door starts to close, Catch's face "follows" the sliding door with a funny look for the boy. We hear Tommy laugh as the door closes. Catch carries his new possessions to his apartment. EXT. OLDER HOUSE - LATE DAY A well-kept older home, well-planted, pretty. A woman of nearly 60 is tending the flowers. She hears someone approaching the gate in the wooden fence. She looks up. Sharon is at the gate, in uniform, on her dinner break. The older woman is her MOTHER, Elaine Pogue. There is an old strain between them, a sadness -- and a nervousness in Elaine. She's a quiet woman. She smiles at her daughter as Sharon comes through the gate. They hug tentatively, a lot of baggage here. Sharon turns to the garden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's looking great, Mom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, honey. It's the best year ever for the impatiens. The very best. There is a beat of awkward silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's go in. INT. POGUE HOME - DAY As they enter. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: It's a bit dark inside, older furniture, lots of keepsake clutter and photos. Sharon is restless in here -- bad memories.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looks the same. Still smells like cigarettes. I thought he quit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's down to six a day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your hair looks nice. Her Mother touches her hair, self-consciously. She can't help glancing at her daughter in all that gear -- bullet-proof vest under her shirt, radio, cuffs -- and that gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you well? Sharon steps close to the mantel. There is a photo of her there, graduating from the police academy, a professional, not a family shot. She is surprised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess I'm well. Is this always here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.   It's always there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did Larry tell you I came by where he's working? Is that why you called me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I called because we want to invite you to our renewal of vows. It's three weeks from Saturday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's 'we.'     You said 'we' want to invite you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The family. Sharon takes that in, still looking about. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How come you're renewing your vows?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's sort of... a fresh start.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your idea?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Both of us. It's a way of... having the marriage blessed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wasn't it blessed before? Her Mother sighs, sad for all the trouble between them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sherry... of course it was blessed. You just...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just what, Mom?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You just think about the bad, and you never remember the good. I wish you remembered the good. Sharon stares deeply at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry.  I wish I did, too. (then, almost like a child) Does he? Remember any good about me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. He doesn't hate you. He just... still feels hurt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hurt?    I hurt him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Being arrested like that. Somebody doesn't forget that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh? How come you forgot what he did? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It wasn't as bad -- you always make it sound worse. And it hasn't been that way for years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm glad it hasn't been that way. That means it worked, Mom. That was the point. That's why I did it. Christ. Why do I get punished for it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey, nobody's punishing you. We're inviting you. Will you come?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course I'll come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We didn't think you'd want to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not? Now her Mother shows a trace of fear.     She says gently...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We don't want any trouble... on that day. Please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom, I'm your daughter. I don't want any trouble -- ever. I'll come to the ceremony. I won't come to argue, and I won't come in uniform. They each get a small, sad smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's on the 23rd. Saint Monica's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like you to send me an invitation. Mrs. Vander said it's a beautiful invitation. Her Mother starts to leave the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll show you. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom. I'd like to get one... in the mail... from my family. Okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Sharon goes to the door, then stops and turns, letting her guard down all the way to say...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell Dad... thanks. And she leaves. EXT. SHARON'S APARTMENT - EVENING Sharon is climbing the   outdoor staircase to her apartment, tired after   her shift, drained a bit   by her visit home. When she    reaches her door she sees   that a long-stemmed rose has   been masking-taped to her   door. Written on the masking   tape is: "Catch Lambert"    and a phone number. She pauses, staring at this, gets a little grin. INT. SHARON'S BEDROOM - NIGHT (HOURS LATER) Sharon is dressed for bed in a sleep shirt, lying on the bed, surrounded by old photos and a couple of photo albums from her girlhood. In a vase on her bed table is Catch's rose. Sharon is feeling blue, looking at her young self within the family that has shut her out. She closes the book, angry at herself for nearly crying. She sits up and catches sight of the rose and rummages in the drawer and pulls out the tape with Catch's phone number on it. She's very conflicted    about this. She puts the tape down, but it sticks to    her fingers. She tears it off and tries to throw it onto    the table, but it hangsoff her thumb. She sighs and     steels herself and dialsthe number. INT. CATCH'S APARTMENT He has bought a shelf unit that "needs some assembly" and he's at work with a screwdriver, his new chair and table nearby, the phone on the floor. PHONE RINGS, and he picks it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FULL SHOT As we INTERCUT the call:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have a machine?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have an answering machine?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you hang up please, and I'll call your machine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why? She hangs up. He stares at the phone a moment, bewildered. He hangs up, and his PHONE RINGS. He lets it ring. His MACHINE comes on with no recording, only a BEEP.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi. Maybe we can... have breakfast or something. I get up early and run in Ballard Park. There's a Denny's across from the park. Like eight or so. If you're there, you're there. She hangs up, sighs a heavy one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, God. And she falls back on her bed. INT. DENNY'S - MORNING Catch walks in, glances at the clock. It's 7 A.M. He's nervous -- and excited. He takes a seat where he can watch the park, the runners. He waits. INT. SHARON'S APARTMENT - MORNING She has tossed and turned all night. She is awake, turning to look at her clock-radio. It is 7:14. She raises a hand over it. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: It changes to   7:15 and the RADIO COMES ON.    She slams her hand down on   it, cutting it OFF. She lays    back and heaves a sigh   that becomes a moan, sits up   again and picks up the   phone, dials the number on the   tape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, don't pick up. Look, I didn't sleep much and anyway this is a bad idea. I was feeling funky last night and I'm all right now so let's just leave it where it's at. Bye. Oh, thanks for the... Bye. She hangs up and lays back down and pounds her head into the pillow and covers herself, even her head, with the sheet. INT. DENNY'S - MORNING Catch is waiting, watching out the window.      It's 8:05, until we...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn it! She stumbles out of the bedroom to her door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?!     Who?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Jesus. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: She opens the door.    He wears a stern look.     She is not apologetic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was just falling asleep. Finally.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We made a date.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It wasn't a 'date.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, an 'appointment.'     I keep my appointments. She gives an exasperated moan and turns to stagger back to bed. He closes the door and follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I called you.    I called you at seven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I get up early. I walked there. I waited there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Check your messages. She heads for the bed, passing a     mirror, looking at her rumpled self and groaning at the     sight.  She climbs into bed and snuggles there and puts     the sheet over her head. He is entering the bedroom. He      carries a Denny's take- out bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need more sleep. Come back in a month.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come back? What makes you think I'd come back here? The lump under the sheet says...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then why are you here? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm here to tell you that when you tell someone you're going to be somewhere then that someone rearranges his life and you should be more aware of that and a lot more considerate instead of just... She has come out from under the sheet and is watching him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's in the bag?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?   None of your business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you bring some coffee?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think you deserve coffee?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What else did you bring?   Food?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You definitely don't deserve food. I've got coffee, sugar, sweetener, non-dairy...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just black.   Black. Thanks. She sits up. He hands her the coffee.         She sips, relishing the sip, then studies him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what kind of life did you rearrange in order to get to Denny's? You never said one word about yourself last night. What d'you do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the difference?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the difference?! You're standing in my bedroom. That's the difference. Who are you? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Somebody who keeps appointments.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're ducking. Don't duck. (then a thought) Oh, shit -- you're married, right? Convinced -- she picks up one of the throw pillows from the bed and tosses it at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't believe you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't believe me?   Give me back the coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me the coffee. She hands him the coffee. He hits her with the pillow and hands her back the coffee. He has made her smile, but she continues, half teasing now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, God. Oh, wait -- you're involved in some criminal activity, aren't you? Great -- That's all I need.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My name is Catch Lambert. I don't work. I don't commit any crimes. I like being with you. We can start from here -- from now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bullshit. I'm... I let you in here. I'm not going to be some fool. I need the details.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I need to start from here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's ridiculous. Why? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the way it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh.   Your rules.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My rules.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus. Okay. Fine. I don't really want to know you anyway. Goodbye. He is conflicted -- but he won't relent. He walks to the door. She stares, waiting. But he never turns around. He walks out. She is mystified, exasperated. She hears her FRONT DOOR CLOSE. She puts the coffee on her bed table -- and finds herself staring at that damn rose. She suddenly gets up and begins to dress hurriedly -- with a plan. EXT. BOULEVARD - DAY Sharon is driving, speeding a bit, getting to Catch's building ahead of him. EXT. CATCH'S BUILDING - DAY He approaches his apartment building, unlocks the front door, walks in the entrance area. Now we see, across the street, Sharon exit her car and follow him. EXT. BUILDING - DAY The front door has locked automatically. Outside there is a panel of buzzers and apartment numbers. Sharon hits all the buttons. Somebody BUZZES her in. INT. LOBBY - DAY Sharon enters, looks at the elevators. It's not moving. She goes to the stairs, listens, hears him TRUDGING UP the stairway. She follows silently. INT. HALLWAY - DAY As Catch reaches his apartment door, unlocks it, opens it and walks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. CATCH'S APARTMENT - DAY Before he can close the DOOR behind him, it BANGS open wider, startling him -- and Sharon is in the doorway, staring hard at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sarcastic) Can I come in? She walks in and closes the door and starts looking around as he says...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.   Sure.   Come in. Despite his recent "decorating" the apartment is still nearly empty. No books, magazines, photographs, no clutter of life. She glances into the equally sterile kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You live here? Nobody lives here. This place is some kind of front, a scam, a drop -- or what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is what you told me about -- right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your interrogation.      Do I need a lawyer? He has made her look at herself, and take a breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just don't want to be jerked around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then tell me straight out.      Who are you? He is silent, and she starts to leave.     Moment of truth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it you're looking for? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your life.    I don't want any surprises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is it. I sleep here. I walk around town. That's all of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's all of it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Except for you -- the way I feel about you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Surprising.    I thought it was impossible.    I thought I was...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You thought you were what?       Gay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dead.   In a way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm supposed to understand that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Did you ever wonder what 'scratch' meant, when people say, 'we'll start from scratch'? This is scratch. We can start from here. She looks at him, looks at his empty place, his non-life, and back at him again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.    I just don't know. She breaks off the stare and heads for the door.     He watches her go. EXT. UPSCALE NEIGHBORHOOD - DAY (SAME DAY) As Catch charges up the stairs to the wide porch of Mrs. Chu's well-kept home, carrying a grocery bag, head full of his thoughts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. MRS. CHU'S HOME - DAY As Catch enters. She is watching TV. He does glance into the living room briefly to throw her a quick hello smile, before moving to the kitchen. She SNAPS OFF the TV and begins turning the photos face down as she sends her voice to the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I remember that. That was a smile. INT. KITCHEN - DAY He is putting groceries away as she rolls into the room. He doesn't look at her, tries to be casual, but his thoughts are bubbling out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know the cop -- the woman cop? She... visited me. Mrs. Chu registers surprise at this, but keeps it covered and casual.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh?   Where did she sit?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have a chair now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're... seeing her? He darkens a bit as he works.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She has a lot of questions.    She wants to know everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course she does. Everybody does.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We could start from today.    What's so wrong with that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell her. The can in Catch's hand bangs on the cupboard, and he stops, suddenly uptight. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell her what? Mrs. Chu comes closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell her, Catch. Tell somebody. It's been almost two years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nora...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Every time I tell somebody, it gets a little bit easier. I'm not saying it goes... His next warning is tough and absolute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nora! She is silenced. The moment hangs. She rolls her chair to him, takes a box of cookies out of his hand, opens the box and eats one, defusing the moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nice? He starts to work again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's tough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She pretty?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That doesn't matter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is pretty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's sort of pissed-off at me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Apologize.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For what? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It doesn't matter. We like it when men apologize. He stares at her a while.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry I yelled at you. She smiles and hands him the box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have a cookie.     See? INT. POLICE REPORT ROOM - NIGHT Sharon is typing at the computer, dark and dogged in her work.  Lieutenant Sanderman is watching her through the glass wall of the watch commander's office. He comes out of the office and moves to where Sharon is typing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sharon...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lieutenant... We can see the   computer screen now. Sharon is searching for any prior   record of "Catch Lambert" -- arrests, convictions.    She has several "Carl Lamberts" on the screen, even a   "Casper," no Catch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anything bothering you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?   What'd I do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing. I'm talking about your general attitude lately. Sharon stops typing.     She can find nothing.    She clears the screen, sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My attitude's fine. End of a long day. I'm tired.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Family matters getting to you? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Family?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your brother, Larry...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about Larry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know Nester -- on the Culver City P.D.? He went out on a violent domestic dispute yesterday. A neighbor called it in. It got a little ugly. No arrest -- a warning. This hits her hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larry.     Oh Christ.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nester said it's not the first time. Sharon is quiet a while, taking it in, shaken by it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks for telling me. EXT. RESIDENTIAL STREET (CULVER CITY) - DAY (NEXT MORNING) Sharon, not in uniform, is approaching Larry's house. It has a small yard with kids' toys strewn about and a tire- swing. She walks up on the porch and RINGS the DOORBELL. She hears VOICES inside, LARRY AND KATHY, a quick murmuring, low-voice argument, can't make out the words. In a moment, Larry opens the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus, you're up early.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted to catch you before you went to work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you were on late shifts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't sleep much. Can I come in?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. LARRY'S HOME - LIVING ROOM - DAY The place is messy.    A TV can be heard -- CARTOONS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's Kath?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's busy with Larry Jr. right now. Sharon nods, but then walks past him. INT. CHILD'S ROOM - DAY As Sharon walks into this toy-strewn room. Larry Jr. is sitting on the floor, watching a small TV. Kathy is not with him. Sharon kneels beside the boy a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Champ. But he stays focused on the TV, some darkness, some unsayable worry in his eyes. She picks up a toy car, speaks softly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Y'know, they call this one a woody 'cause it has wood on the sides.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. Now he looks at her with sad and bottomless eyes. She is hurting for him. Larry is now in the doorway. Sharon kisses the child's head and walks out, passing her brother.
direction.name: direction
